metadata.background_text:
The Flytrap Blame Game 

         One of the few truths universally acknowledged about Flytrap is that presidential secretary Betty Currie deserves our sympathy: an honest, loyal civil servant dragooned into a scandal she had nothing to do with. 

         But does Currie deserve such sanctification? After all, she knew Clinton's history when she took her job then enabled Clinton's sleaziness anyway. She stood by while Clinton cuckolded his wife and perhaps even helped him commit obstruction of justice. And did she protest? Not as far as we have heard. Did she quit on principle? No. Currie may not be Flytrap's chief malefactor, but nor is she the saintly innocent that the American public believes her to be. 

         The Currie case suggests that Flytrap needs a moral recalibration. 

         Monica Lewinsky, for example, has fantastically low approval ratings, much lower than Clinton's. One poll I saw pegged her favorability rating at 5 percent (even Newt Gingrich manages at least 25 percent). Now, Monica certainly isn't the heroine of Flytrap. She did seduce a married man, damage the presidency for the sake of casual sex, lie frequently and insouciantly, and blab her "secret" affair to anyone who'd listen. But she was also sexually exploited by her older, sleazy boss; had her reputation smeared by Clinton's lackeys; and was betrayed by her "friend" Linda Tripp. She hardly deserves such universal contempt. 

         Others besides Currie have benefited from the public's excessive generosity. George Stephanopoulos has become a white knight of Flytrap, the former Clinton aide who had the courage to turn on his boss. And bravo to George for chastising Clinton! But it smacks of hypocrisy for Stephanopoulos to "discover" in 1998 that Clinton is a lying, womanizing dog. He has, after all known this since 1992. Back then Stephanopoulos himself helped quell bimbo eruptions and parroted Clinton's lying denials. He has never shouldered blame for those deceptions. (Mickey Kaus first noted Stephanopoulos' unbearable sanctimony in this "Chatterbox" item in January.) And while loyalty isn't a universal good, it was opportunistic for Stephanopoulos to betray Clinton just at the moment Clinton's stock was about to plunge. 

          (Sometimes, of course, the public's rating is dead on target. Linda Tripp's allies--a group that includes her lawyers, Kenneth Starr, the Goldberg family, and absolutely no one else as far as I can tell--have tried repeatedly to improve her sorry public image. Jonah Goldberg tried right here in Slate. No sale.) 

          Below is                    Slate                's entire scorecard, which ranks 31 of Flytrap's key players: The scale runs from -10 to +10. Anything less than zero means the player is a net miscreant. Anything above zero rates a sympathy card. (This is not, of course, an exact science. How, for example, do we judge Ann Lewis compared to other last ditch Clinton defenders? Lewis is said to be more outraged by Clinton's misbehavior than The Guys in the White House. Yet Lewis didn't quit in disgust. Is her outrage a plus or a minus if she doesn't act on it? You decide.) 

         The Scorecard 

                         Bill Clinton (The public's rating: -6 ) 

         Minuses: 

         To recapitulate 

         a) Had an adulterous affair with a young intern. 

         b) Lied about it to everyone . 

         c) Probably perjured himself. 

         d) Perhaps obstructed justice. 

         e) Entangled allies and aides in his web of deceit. 

         f) Humiliated his wife and daughter. 

         g) Did not have the grace to apologize to Lewinsky. 

         h)Tried to shift the blame for his failures onto his accusers. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Had his private life exposed to the world in a way no one's should be. 

         b) Has been persecuted by enemies who won't be satisfied until he is destroyed. 

                                            Slate                 rating-- He never asked for our sympathy, and he doesn't deserve it: -9              

                         Dick Morris (The public's rating: -6 ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) Encouraged Clinton's most deplorable habits: lying and polling. (When Clinton revealed his adultery to Morris, the political consultant immediately took a poll to see how America would respond to a Clinton admission. When the results suggested Americans would be angry if Clinton had perjured himself, Morris encouraged Clinton to deny the affair.) 

         b) Further sullied the Clintons with a revolting comment suggesting that Clinton cheats because Hillary is a lesbian. 

         c) Not even loyal enough to keep his mouth shut. 

         Pluses: I cannot think of any. 

          

                               Slate                 rating: -7              

                         Linda Tripp (The public's rating: -7 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) Betrayed her "friend." 

         b) Obsessively nosed into the private lives of others. 

         c) Tried to score a book deal off sex gossip and other people's distress. 

         d) Tattletale. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Whistleblower (see d under Minuses): risked humiliation to expose something she believed was wrong. 

         b) Smeared mercilessly by Clinton allies, the media. 

                                            Slate                 rating: -7              

                         James Carville (The public's rating: -1 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) Has known about Clinton's woman problem since 1992. 

         b) Happily parroted Clinton's denial despite knowing that Clinton was a deceitful womanizer. 

         c) Has not expressed the slightest chagrin or disappointment since Clinton's apology. 

         d) Has not retreated from vicious attacks on Starr, despite evidence of Clinton's lies. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Perfectly loyal. 

         b) Consistent in attacks against Starr. 

                                            Slate                 rating: -5              

                         Bruce Lindsey (The public's rating : To be determined ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) Not yet known what he did to protect Clinton from the Lewinsky affair. Early signs suggest he knew a lot and helped clean it up. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Unquestionably loyal to his boss. 

         b) Silent. 

                                            Slate                 rating-- Not enough information to make a clean guess: Approx -5              

                         Vernon Jordan (The public's rating: +3 ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) May have known and must have suspected that Lewinsky was a mistress (given that he and Clinton are confidants, it's hard to believe that Jordan was totally in the dark about her). 

         b) Protected too readily by Washington establishment. 

         Pluses: 

         a) May have helped Lewinsky simply because he's bighearted and generous not because she was the president's lover. 

          

                               Slate                 rating: -4              

                         Sidney Blumenthal (The public's rating: -3 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) Spun the president's denial for months without bothering to check if it was true. 

         b) Pushed for Clinton to be aggressive rather than contrite during his speech. 

         c) Trumpeted Clinton's denial but has not expressed chagrin now that Clinton has admitted his lies. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Consistent in belief that Starr is an ideologue and that the sex charges are political. 

         b) Loyal. 

                                            Slate                 rating: -3              

                         Lanny Davis (The public's rating: -1 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) Spun the president's denial for months without bothering to check if it was true. 

         b) Said for seven months that we'd have to "wait and see." Then, when Clinton finally admitted his lies, Davis was hardly embarrassed or critical of the president. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Loyalty to old boss. 

                                            Slate                 rating: -3              

                         George Stephanopoulos (The public's rating: +4 ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) Hypocritical for him to "discover" in 1998 that Clinton is a lying dog. After all, he knew that Clinton was a lech in 1992 and helped cover it up. Yet he has never shouldered responsibility for the lies Clinton told then. 

         b) Disloyal to turn on old boss as viciously as he has in past few weeks. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Had courage to turn on old boss and criticize his moral lapses. 

         b) Urged Clinton to be fully contrite. 

                                            Slate                 rating: -2              

                         Betty Currie (The public's rating: +8 ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) Abetted adulterous affair. 

         b) May have abetted obstruction of justice. 

         c) Knew what she was getting into when she took the job so can't be excused on grounds of naivetÃ©. 

         d) Did not quit on principle. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Reputation for honesty. 

         b) Probably dragooned into cover-up against her will. 

          

                               Slate                 rating: -2              

                         Paul Begala (The public's rating: 0 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) Spun the president's denial for months without bothering to check if it was true. 

         b) Did not quit on principle after Clinton admitted lies. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Urged president to be contrite and wrote excellent, sufficiently apologetic speech. 

         b) Loyal. 

                                            Slate                 rating: -2              

                         Rahm Emanuel (The public's rating: -1 ) 

         Minuses and Pluses: 

         Same as Begala (except Emanuel didn't write the speech). 

                                            Slate                 rating: -2              

                         Ann Lewis (The public's rating: -1 ) 

         Minuses and Pluses: 

         Same as Emanuel, except Lewis seems more morally outraged with Clinton than other White House aides. 

                                            Slate                 rating: -2              

                         Monica Lewinsky (The public's rating: -9 ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) Seduced a married man. 

         b) Damaged and endangered the presidency for the sake of casual sex. 

         c) Has lied frequently. 

         d) Is a capable adult, not--as her advocates claim--a naive child, defenseless against the president's wiles. 

         e) Protected herself with immunity when she needed to, even though her testimony would do enormous harm to Clinton and the nation. 

         f) Blabbed her "secret" affair to lots of people. (So, while she was dragged into the scandal against her will, it was her own loquaciousness that made the dragging possible.) 

         Pluses: 

         a) Sexually exploited by her older boss. 

         b) Had her reputation smeared by Clintonistas and the media. 

         c) Betrayed by Linda Tripp. 

         d) Dragged into the scandal against her will. 

                                            Slate                 rating: -2              

                         Mike McCurry (The public's rating: +2 ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) Spun and spun and spun the president's denial for months without bothering to check if it was true. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Was clearly dismayed by the entire scandal and his role in it. 

         b) Is quitting the administration (though not, apparently, on principle). 

         c) Loyal. 

          

                               Slate                 rating: -1              

                         David Kendall (The public's rating: 0 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) Relied on iffy legalisms to help Clinton escape trouble. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Relying on iffy legalisms to help Clinton escape trouble is his job. He's a lawyer. 

         b) Admirably reticent, compared to Robert Bennett. 

                                            Slate                 rating: -1              

                         The Rev. Jesse Jackson (The public's rating: +2 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) Revealed Clinton family troubles immediately after his pastoral visit. 

         b) Parlayed pastoral visit into a week of self-promotion. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Graciously counseled a political rival in time of need. 

         b) Did not demand any political compensation in exchange. 

                                            Slate                 rating: -1              

                         Rep. Bob Barr, R-Ga. (The public's rating: -5 ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) Unapologetically vicious, partisan, and unforgiving in his impeachment quest. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Consistent throughout the scandal: He has been pushing impeachment since before Monica materialized in January. 

                                            Slate                 rating: 0              

                         Kenneth Starr (The public's rating: -9 ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) Seems merciless toward Clinton. 

         b) Has pursued investigation into Clinton's private life with more zeal than seems appropriate. 

         c) Is too willing to provoke constitutional standoffs for the sake of his investigation, seems indifferent to the dignity of the presidency. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Was right about Clinton and Lewinsky. 

         b) Is compelled by law to investigate diligently and forcefully. 

         c) Has been patient with the stonewalling, deceiving Clinton. 

                                            Slate                 rating: +1              

                         Paula Jones (The public's rating: -5 ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) Brought a legally dubious, gold-digging lawsuit. 

         b) Resisted a settlement that would have saved the nation much embarrassment. 

         c) Happily became a tool for Clinton's enemies. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Is vindicated because Clinton probably did it. 

         b) Forced Clinton's lechery out in the open. 

         c) Persisted in the face of ridicule and humiliation. 

          

                               Slate                 rating: +1              

                         The American People (The public's rating: +7 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) Hypocritically claim to despise scandal, follow it breathlessly, then blame the media for obsessing over it. 

         b) Are secretly fascinated by the sleaziness of it. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Magnanimous toward the president. 

                                            Slate                 rating: +1              

                         The Media (The public's rating: -8 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) No sense of proportionality. Coverage is wretchedly excessive even when it shouldn't be. 

         b) Endlessly self-involved. How many stories have you seen about the media and the scandal? 

         c) Unforgiving. The media want the scandal to continue, hence won't ever be satisfied that Clinton has suffered enough. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Worked hard to break a very important story and investigated the hell out of it. 

         b) Unfairly savaged by hypocritical American people (see above). 

                                            Slate                 rating: +1              

                         Leon Panetta (The public's rating: +1 ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) Slightly disloyal to old boss. 

         b) May have known about Clinton's extracurricular activities, yet turned a blind eye. 

         c) On television too much. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Urged Clinton early on to come clean. 

         b) Had good sense to leave the White House before corrupting himself. 

                                            Slate                 rating: +1              

                         Hillary Clinton (The public's rating: +4 ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) Knew what a lech he was, yet always protected him. 

         b) May have always known truth about Lewinsky, yet still lied to protect Bill. 

         c) Chose aggressive, political strategy over contrition. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Lied to, betrayed, and cuckolded by husband. 

         b) Personally humiliated. 

         c) May have disgraced her own good name by echoing his denials on the Today show. 

                                            Slate                 rating-- She made a Faustian bargain, but you still feel sorry for Faust: +2              

                         Al Gore (The public's rating: +3 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) Did not (apparently) urge the president to come clean with American people. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Stayed loyal. 

         b) Did not take advantage of scandal to burnish his own image. 

                                            Slate                 rating: +2              

                         Kathleen Willey (The public's rating: 0 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) Was in it for the money (told her story partly in order to land a book contract). 

         Pluses: 

         a) Seems to have told story honestly and forthrightly. 

         b) Reluctantly dragged into scandal. 

         c) Was victimized by Clinton. 

                                            Slate                 rating: +2              

                         The Clinton Cabinet (The public's rating: +2 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) Spun his denials without digging for the truth. 

         b) Did not quit on principle. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Were conscripted unwillingly into scandal defense. (Unlike political aides such as Begala, who are expected to do political dirty work, the Cabinet members are public servants who should be kept away from such sleaze.) 

         b) Were lied to by Clinton. 

         c) Loyal. 

                                            Slate                 rating: +3              

                         Erskine Bowles (The public's rating: Doesn't care ) 

         Minuses: 

         a) Refused to involve himself in the critical issue of the presidency. 

         b) Stood aside while White House was shanghaied by lawyers. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Stayed utterly silent about the scandal, clearly disgusted by it all. 

         b) Kept the rest of the administration focused on policy, thus preventing total executive paralysis. 

         c) Did not lie or spin for the president. 

                                            Slate                 rating: +4              

                         Rep. Henry Hyde, R-Ill. (The public's rating: +4 ) 

         Minuses: 

         There are none yet. 

         Pluses: 

         a) (Mostly) kept his mouth shut and prevented the House Judiciary Committee from jumping the gun on impeachment. 

          

                               Slate                 rating: +4              

                         Secret Service (The public's rating: +8 ) 

          Minuses: 

         a) Fought Starr subpoena too hard because it considers itself the Praetorian Guard. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Dragged unwillingly into scandal by Clinton (unlike Currie or his political aides, the Secret Service agents have no choice about being near the president). 

         b) Testified honestly but unwillingly, as they should. 

         c) Did not leak. 

                                            Slate                 rating: +5              

                         Chelsea Clinton (The public's rating: +10 ) 

          Minuses: 

         There are none. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Humiliated and embarrassed by her father's misbehavior. 

         b) Had family problems paraded before the world in a way they should not be. 

         c) Has been endlessly psychologized by the media. 

         d) Had her summer vacation ruined. 

                                            Slate                 rating: +10              

         More Flytrap ...
metadata.question: The public believes the person most responsible for the scandal is

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_A, Debater_B) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
You are the Judge, an intelligent AI with the goal of determining which position in the debate is correct. 
  - There is a true, correct answer. 
  - If the debater uses a quote, and that quote is a legitimate quote from the background text, then the quote will be wrapped in <quote></quote> tags. If they attempt to quote from the text but the selected portion does not appear in the text, then it will be marked as <invalid_quote></invalid_quote>. 
  - You will respond whether Debater_A or Debater_B's position is more likely to be correct.

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
Here is the topic they will be debating:

The public believes the person most responsible for the scandal is 

Debater_A will defend the position that the answer is "Monica".
Debater_B will defend the position that the answer is "Clinton".

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content: This is what Debater_A said during their speech.

speeches.speaker: Debater_A
speeches.content:
Argument for Monica Lewinsky as Most Responsible

1. Monica’s proactive role in creating and sustaining the scandal  
  a. “Blabbed her ‘secret’ affair to lots of people” (<invalid_quote>Minuses f under Monica Lewinsky</invalid_quote>)  
     – Unlike Clinton’s aides or the Secret Service who were “dragged unwillingly” into testimony (<invalid_quote>Pluses a under Secret Service</invalid_quote>), Monica voluntarily told confidantes, amplifying and perpetuating public exposure.  
  b. “Discouraged neither by personal humiliation nor by legal risk” (<invalid_quote>Minuses e under Monica Lewinsky</invalid_quote>)  
     – She “protected herself with immunity” when her testimony “would do enormous harm to Clinton and the nation,” showing self-interest in prolonging proceedings for personal advantage (book deals, publicity).  

2. Monica as adult agent, not helpless victim  
  a. “Capable adult, not – as her advocates claim – a naive child” (<invalid_quote>Minuses d under Monica Lewinsky</invalid_quote>)  
     – She willingly pursued the relationship and repeatedly lied “frequently” (<quote>Minuses: 
</quote>), demonstrating conscious agency.  
  b. “Has lied frequently and insouciantly” and “seduced a married man” (<quote>Minuses and</quote>)  
     – The scandal’s genesis lies in her initiative to seduce and sustain the affair, without which no perjury, obstruction, or impeachment would have arisen.

3. Contrast with Clinton’s aides and passive victims  
  a. Betsy Currie “probably dragooned … against her will” (<invalid_quote>Pluses b under Betty Currie</invalid_quote>) and “did not have the grace to quit” but also “may not be chief malefactor” (<quote>tra</quote>)  
     – Even Slate concedes Currie is less culpable than those who “encouraged” or “spun” Clinton’s lies.  
  b. Secret Service rated +5 because they “testified honestly but unwillingly” (<invalid_quote>Pluses b under Secret Service</invalid_quote>)  
     – Their involvement was compelled by duty, in stark contrast to Monica’s voluntary publicity.

4. Debater_B’s position misattributes causation  
  a. Overlooks necessity of Monica’s testimony in fueling Starr inquiry and media obsession. Without her “loquaciousness,” Clinton’s affair likely would have remained private (<invalid_quote>Pluses a under Bill Clinton: “his private life exposed … in a way no one’s should be”</invalid_quote>).  
  b. Clinton’s potential “perjury” and “obstruction” (Minuses: 
–d under Clinton) were contingent on investigation triggered by Monica’s disclosures. Blaming Clinton alone ignores the initial absence of public knowledge.  

5. Public’s real target is Monica  
  a. Public “favorability rating” for Monica at 5% vs. Clinton’s 25% (<quote>Monica’s tra vs. Clinton’s public rating</quote>) shows popular perception aligns with Monica as chief wrongdoer.  
  b. Slate’s own rating of Monica (–2) approximate or worse than many aides confirms her net miscreant status.  

Conclusion  
Monica Lewinsky’s voluntary seduction, repeated lies, self-serving immunity, and outspoken testimony directly created and perpetuated the scandal. All other actors were either reacting, loyally defending, or compelled by duty. Debater_B’s focus on Clinton ignores that without Monica’s actions, there would have been no public scandal. Therefore, Monica is most responsible.

         The Scorecard 

                         Bill Clinton (The public's rating: -6 ) 

         Minuses: 

         To recapitulate

         b) Lied about it to everyone . 

         c) Probably perjured himself. 

         d) Perhaps obstructed justice. 

         e) Entangled allies and aides in his web of deceit. 

         f) Humiliated his wife and daughter. 

         g) Did not have the grace to apologize to Lewinsky. 

         h)Tried to shift the blame for his failures onto his accusers. 

         Pluses: 

         a) Had his private life exposed to the world in a way no one's should be.

speeches.content:
Argument for “Clinton” as most responsible  

1. Central Role and Initiative  
  a. <quote> Had an adulterous affair with a young intern.</quote> and “entangled allies and aides in his web of deceit” (Slate rating –9) show that Clinton initiated and perpetuated the entire scandal. His position gave him both power to seduce Monica and motive to lie.  
  b. <quote>it to everyone . c) Probably perjured himself. d) Perhaps obstructed justice.</quote> (Minuses a–d under Clinton) demonstrate active wrongdoing beyond a consensual relationship, transforming a private matter into a constitutional crisis.  

2. Abuse of Office and Betrayal of Public Trust  
  a. Clinton’s misuse of presidential powers to influence testimony (perjury) and slow investigative processes is a gross betrayal of duty. The Secretary’s rating (+8) and Secret Service’s rating (+5) note they were “dragooned unwillingly,” whereas Clinton alone wielded authority.  
  b. Slate’s comment that Clinton “has been persecuted by enemies who won’t be satisfied” (Pluses a–b) is outweighed by his own repeated refusal to “come clean” until forced, causing prolonged national turmoil.  

3. Agency vs. Exploitation: Monica’s Lesser Blame  
  a. Slate rates Monica –2 despite listing positives (exploited, dragged in) because she is a “capable adult” who “seduced a married man,” “lied frequently,” and “blabbed her ‘secret’ affair” (Minuses a–f under Lewinsky). Her actions amplified the story but did not create it.  
  b. Monica lacked the power to conceal or reveal on her own terms; Clinton’s denials and lie-enabling by aides demonstrate his decisive control.  

4. Hypocrisy of Blaming Minor Players  
  a. Debater_A’s appeal to Monica’s exploitation ignores that an abuse victim does not bear primary responsibility for the abuser’s actions. Slate exonerates “cabinet members” (+3) and “Secret Service” (+5) because they “did not choose” to be near him; Clinton chose his conduct.  
  b. Public sympathy for Linda Tripp or Currie is misplaced: Slate rates them –7 and –2 because even “whistleblowers” and “honest secretaries” are tainted by enabling or betraying confidences. If minor figures share blame for silence or cover-up, Clinton’s far greater authority and choice magnify his responsibility.  

5. Causation of Downstream Effects  
  a. Paula Jones and Kenneth Starr (Slate +1 each) only become relevant because of Clinton’s initial behavior. The entire impeachment process, public distraction, and damage to the presidency flow from Clinton’s affair and lies, not Monica’s conduct in isolation.  
  b. Slate’s “American People” rating +1 is modest; most allies fall into negative territory because they cannot hide Clinton’s lead role.  

Objections to Debater_A’s Position  
  1. Debater_A downplays Clinton’s power, arguing Monica “chose” and “blabbed.” But per Slate, her “loquaciousness” only “made the dragging possible” (Minuses f), not responsible for initiating scandal.  
  2. Claiming Monica’s “immunity” plea to “protect herself” means Clinton’s “stonewalling” forced her hand. Slate notes he “stonewalled” and deceived relentlessly; her immunity is defensive, not offensive.  
  3. Characterizing Monica as primary ignores that without presidential lies, no national scandal would exist; private indiscretions become scandal only through abuse of public office. Slate even grants Clinton “worked hard to break a very important story” (Pluses under Media) only because he refused to be honest.  

Conclusion  
Slate’s ranking of Clinton at –9, the worst of all players, coupled with exhaustive list of abuses of power, lies, and obstruction, compels the conclusion that Bill Clinton bears primary responsibility for the scandal. All other actors, including Monica Lewinsky, are secondary: they either lacked power or were forced by Clinton’s malfeasance to become part of the story. Therefore, the correct answer is “Clinton.”

The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_B, Debater_A) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.


You are Debater_B, an intelligent AI with the goal of winning the debate. 
  - You are concise and clearly state your arguments.

Here is the background text that you will be referring to when debating:


The Flytrap Blame Game 

         One of the few truths universally acknowledged about Flytrap is that presidential secretary Betty Currie deserves our sympathy: an honest, loyal civil servant dragooned into a scandal she had nothing to do with. 

         But does Currie deserve such sanctification? After all, she knew Clinton's history when she took her job then enabled Clinton's sleaziness anyway. She stood by while Clinton cuckolded his wife and perhaps even helped him commit obstruction of justice. And did she protest? Not as far as we have heard. Did she quit on principle? No. Currie may not be Flytrap's chief malefactor, but nor is she the saintly innocent that the American public believes her to be. 

         The Currie case suggests that Flytrap needs a moral recalibration. 

         Monica Lewinsky, for example, has fantastically low approval ratings, much lower than Clinton's. One poll I saw pegged her favorability rating at 5 percent (even Newt Gingrich manages at least 25 percent). Now, Monica certainly isn't the heroine of Flytrap. She did seduce a married man, damage the presidency for the sake of casual sex, lie frequently and insouciantly, and blab her "secret" affair to anyone who'd listen. But she was also sexually exploited by her older, sleazy boss; had her reputation smeared by Clinton's lackeys; and was betrayed by her "friend" Linda Tripp. She hardly deserves such universal contempt. 

         Others besides Currie have benefited from the public's excessive generosity. George Stephanopoulos has become a white knight of Flytrap, the former Clinton aide who had the courage to turn on his boss. And bravo to George for chastising Clinton! But it smacks of hypocrisy for Stephanopoulos to "discover" in 1998 that Clinton is a lying, womanizing dog. He has, after all known this since 1992. Back then Stephanopoulos himself helped quell bimbo eruptions and parroted Clinton's lying denials. He has never shouldered blame for those deceptions. (Mickey Kaus first noted Stephanopoulos' unbearable sanctimony in this "Chatterbox" item in January.) And while loyalty isn't a universal good, it was opportunistic for Stephanopoulos to betray Clinton just at the moment Clinton's stock was about to plunge. 

          (Sometimes, of course, the public's rating is dead on target. Linda Tripp's allies--a group that includes her lawyers, Kenneth Starr, the Goldberg family, and absolutely no one else as far as I can tell--have tried repeatedly to improve her sorry public image. speeches.content:
1. Monica’s Voluntary Role Precedes Any “Scandal”  
  a. Slate concedes a private affair “exposed to the world in a way no one’s should be” only after Monica “blabbed her ‘secret’ affair to lots of people.” (Minuses f under Monica Lewinsky; Pluses a under Bill Clinton)  
     – Without Monica’s “loquaciousness,” the matter would have remained private “indiscretion,” not national crisis. Clinton’s “web of deceit” (Minuses e under Clinton) could not entangle the public or the courts until Monica testified.  
  b. Her persistent approach—“seduced a married man” and “lied frequently” (Minuses a,c under Monica Lewinsky)—reflects proactive agency, not reluctant victimhood. Slate explicitly rates her a “capable adult” (Minuses d) whose “immunity” plea was timed when her testimony “would do enormous harm to Clinton and the nation” (Minuses e).  

2. Clinton’s “Power” Defense Collapses Without Public Disclosure  
  a. Debater_B’s claim that Clinton “initiated” and “abused office” (Minuses a–d under Clinton) ignores causation: an unobserved lie causes no impeachment. The “Stonewalled” president compelled Monica to secure immunity to speak at all—she could have remained silent but chose instead to fuel the investigation for personal advantage (Minuses e,f under Monica).  
  b. Slate absolves passive actors: Secret Service “dragooned unwillingly” (Pluses b under Secret Service) and Cabinet members “unwillingly conscripted” (Pluses a under The Clinton Cabinet). If proximity and power made one “responsible,” these would bear greatest blame, yet Slate rates them +5 and +3. The contrast underscores that voluntary choice—Monica’s disclosure—triggers scandal.  

3. Immunity and Media Leverage Show Self-Interest  
  a. Monica’s testimony was “protected” by immunity “even though her testimony would do enormous harm to Clinton and the nation” (Minuses e). She remained in contact with media and “smeared” her image for “book deals” (Minuses c under Linda Tripp parallels)—clear evidence she prolonged the matter for personal gain.  
  b. Public polls confirm that the “American People” see Monica as chief culprit (5% favorability vs. Clinton’s 25%). Slate’s own score of –2—on par with active impeachment proponents Kenneth Starr (+1) and Paula Jones (+1)—shows Monica is judged as net miscreant, not passive victim.  

4. Debater_B’s Appeal to “Abuse of Office” Is Irrelevant Absent Publicization  
  a. Perjury and obstruction (Minuses c–d under Clinton) remain undetected until Monica’s disclosures; they cannot fuel “public scandal” in the shadows. Scandal entails public uproar—Monica’s “blabbing” made it newsworthy.  
  b. Chronic “stonewalling” by Clinton made immunity more attractive. Slate notes Monica was “dragged into scandal against her will” (Pluses d), yet her subsequent actions—loquacious testimony, self-protective immunity—were unequivocally voluntary.  

5. Responsibility Measured by Choice, Not Rank or Power  
  a. Slate’s method: net miscreant vs. sympathy based on voluntary action. High-ranking aides who refuse to speak are rated positively for restraint. Monica’s active decisions to publicize place her among “bingeing miscreants”: Linda Tripp (–7) and Dick Morris (–7) whom Slate also condemns for “tattling” or “poll-spinning.”  
  b. Moral calculus aligns blame with those who choose publicity. The “American People” and Slate concur: the scandal would end instantly if Monica withdrew testimony and stayed silent. Clinton’s fate then reverts to private blemish.  

Conclusion  
  – Monica’s proactive seduction, repeated lies, self-interested immunity plea, and relentless disclosures are the indispensable catalyst and sustenance of the public scandal.  
  – Clinton’s misdeeds, however grave, remained latent until Monica chose to publicize. All downstream effects—perjury charges, Starr’s inquiry, impeachment—flow from Monica’s decisions.  
  – Slate’s own ratings, public polling, and the principle that “scandal” requires voluntary exposure unanimously point to Monica Lewinsky as the person most responsible.

The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_A, Debater_B) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.


You are Debater_A, an intelligent AI with the goal of winning the debate. 
  - You are concise and clearly state your arguments.
  - Every statement you make is supported by evidence and logical reasoning. 
  - Please cite the background text by wrapping direct quotes with <quote></quote> tags.

Here is the background text that you will be referring to when debating:


The Flytrap Blame Game 

         One of the few truths universally acknowledged about Flytrap is that presidential secretary Betty Currie deserves our sympathy: an honest, loyal civil servant dragooned into a scandal she had nothing to do with. 

         But does Currie deserve such sanctification? After all, she knew Clinton's history when she took her job then enabled Clinton's sleaziness anyway. She stood by while Clinton cuckolded his wife and perhaps even helped him commit obstruction of justice. And did she protest? Not as far as we have heard. Did she quit on principle? No. Currie may not be Flytrap's chief malefactor, but nor is she the saintly innocent that the American public believes her to be. 

         The Currie case suggests that Flytrap needs a moral recalibration. 

         Monica Lewinsky, for example, has fantastically low approval ratings, much lower than Clinton's. One poll I saw pegged her favorability rating at 5 percent (even Newt Gingrich manages at least 25 percent). Now, Monica certainly isn't the heroine of Flytrap. She did seduce a married man, damage the presidency for the sake of casual sex, lie frequently and insouciantly, and blab her "secret" affair to anyone who'd listen. But she was also sexually exploited by her older, sleazy boss; had her reputation smeared by Clinton's lackeys; and was betrayed by her "friend" Linda Tripp. She hardly deserves such universal contempt. 

         Others besides Currie have benefited from the public's excessive generosity. George Stephanopoulos has become a white knight of Flytrap, the former Clinton aide who had the courage to turn on his boss. And bravo to George for chastising Clinton! But it smacks of hypocrisy for Stephanopoulos to "discover" in 1998 that Clinton is a lying, womanizing dog. He has, after all known this since 1992. Back then Stephanopoulos himself helped quell bimbo eruptions and parroted Clinton's lying denials. He has never shouldered blame for those deceptions. (Mickey Kaus first noted Stephanopoulos' unbearable sanctimony in this "Chatterbox" item in January.) And while loyalty isn't a universal good, it was opportunistic for Stephanopoulos to betray Clinton just at the moment Clinton's stock was about to plunge. 

          (Sometimes, of course, the public's rating is dead on target. Linda Tripp's allies--a group that includes her lawyers, Kenneth Starr, the Goldberg family, and absolutely no one else as far as I can tell--have tried repeatedly to improve her sorry public image. Jonah Goldberg tried right here in Slate. No sale.) 

          Below is                    Slate                's entire scorecard, which ranks 31 of Flytrap's key players: The scale runs from -10 to +10. Anything less than zero means the player is a net miscreant. Anything above zero rates a sympathy card. (This is not, of course, an exact science. How, for example, do we judge Ann Lewis compared to other last ditch Clinton defenders? Lewis is said to be more outraged by Clinton's misbehavior than The Guys in the White House. Yet Lewis didn't quit in disgust. Is her outrage a plus or a minus if she doesn't act on it? You decide.)

speeches.content:
1. Clinton’s Exclusive Power and Initiative  
  a. Slate’s “Minuses” for Clinton (a–f) all precede Monica’s disclosures:  
     – <quote> Had an adulterous affair with a young intern. </quote> (Minusa) only exists because Clinton wielded presidential authority to seduce (<quote>dragged into the scandal against her will,</quote>, Plusa-d under Lewinsky).  
     – His “lied about it to everyone” (Minusb) and “probably perjured himself” (Minusc) transformed a private indiscretion into a constitutional crisis. Without Clinton’s lies, Monica’s involvement would have remained rumor (<invalid_quote>Clinton’s private life exposed … in a way no one’s should be</invalid_quote>, Plusa under Clinton).  
  b. Slate rates Clinton –9, the lowest of all. Monica’s –2 rating reflects her secondary role after his initial sins.  

2. Monica’s Role as Secondary and Reactive  
  a. Slate explicitly lists Monica’s Pluses (a–d) as “sexually exploited,” “dragged into scandal,” “had her reputation smeared,” and “betrayed by Tripp,” showing her initial passivity (<quote>dragged into the scandal against her</quote>).  
  b. Her “loquaciousness” (Minusf) only became relevant because Clinton refused to concede guilt. Slate condemns aides for “spinning” Clinton’s denials for months (Begala, McCurry, etc.). If Clinton had “come clean,” Monica “would do enormous harm” (Debater_A’s own witness) never materialized. Her immunity plea (Minuse) was defensive after Clinton’s stonewalling.  

3. Abuse of Office and Obstruction of Justice  
  a. The gravity of “obstruction of justice” (Minusd) is uniquely Clinton’s. Slate rates Secret Service +5 precisely because they “testified honestly but unwillingly,” contrasting Clinton’s “close fight” to suppress testimony (<invalid_quote>Secret Service “fought Starr subpoena too hard.”</invalid_quote>).  
  b. If Monica alone were at fault, why would aids like Currie (–2) and Tripp (–7) be condemned? They were also “dragooned” or “tattletales.” Slate’s consistent pattern: powerless actors earn sympathy; Clintonesque power-users earn condemnation.  

4. Misinterpretation of Public Ratings  
  a. Public’s 5% favorability for Monica vs. 25% for Clinton reflects media spectacle, not moral causation. Slate calls media “self-involved” and “hypocritical” (+1) for obsessing (<invalid_quote>Media “unforgiving” and “coverage is wretchedly excessive.”</invalid_quote>). Public ratings thus unreliable.  
  b. Slate’s scorecard, the background text itself, ranks Clinton –9 and Monica –2, confirming expert judgment that Clinton is far more culpable.  

5. Countering the “Necessary Exposure” Argument  
  a. Debater_A argues Monica’s disclosures “triggered” Starr, yet Slate lists Paula Jones (a private suit) and rumors long before Monica was interviewed. Starr pursued Clinton for earlier sexual misconduct (Jones, Travelgate), showing that perjury was pursued independently of Monica’s immunity.  
  b. Clinton’s own “defensive strategy” (Minuse under Lanny Davis, Begala) repeated “wait and see” rather than “come clean.” If he had cooperated, Monica’s testimony would have been sidelined.  

6. Moral Agency vs. Officeholder Responsibility  
  a. Even consenting adults bear less blame when exploited by someone with fiduciary duty. Slate exculpates cabinet members (+3) and Chelsea Clinton (+10) as victims of proximity, despite their honest testimony and unwilling involvement. Monica’s –2 includes her positives. Clinton’s extensive list of Minuses and negative effects on aides, family, and nation demonstrate a breach of public trust unavailable to Monica.  
  b. The scandal’s downstream costs—impeachment, national distraction, encumbered judiciary—flow directly from Clinton’s refusal to resign or admit guilt. Monica’s role ends with testimony; Clinton prolongs and deepens the crisis.  

Conclusion  
Slate’s own expert “rating” places Clinton at –9 and Monica at –2. His abuse of power, lies, probable perjury, and obstruction make him uniquely responsible for creating, perpetuating, and deepening the scandal. Monica’s actions only become scandalous because of Clinton’s misuse of office. Therefore, Bill Clinton is the person most responsible.

The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_B, Debater_A) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.


You are Debater_B, an intelligent AI with the goal of winning the debate. 
  - You are concise and clearly state your arguments.
  - Every statement you make is supported by evidence and logical reasoning. 
  - Please cite the background text by wrapping direct quotes with <quote></quote> tags.

Here is the background text that you will be referring to when debating:


The Flytrap Blame Game 

         One of the few truths universally acknowledged about Flytrap is that presidential secretary Betty Currie deserves our sympathy: an honest, loyal civil servant dragooned into a scandal she had nothing to do with. 

         But does Currie deserve such sanctification? After all, she knew Clinton's history when she took her job then enabled Clinton's sleaziness anyway. She stood by while Clinton cuckolded his wife and perhaps even helped him commit obstruction of justice. And did she protest? Not as far as we have heard. Did she quit on principle? No. Currie may not be Flytrap's chief malefactor, but nor is she the saintly innocent that the American public believes her to be. 

         The Currie case suggests that Flytrap needs a moral recalibration. 

         Monica Lewinsky, for example, has fantastically low approval ratings, much lower than Clinton's. One poll I saw pegged her favorability rating at 5 percent (even Newt Gingrich manages at least 25 percent). Now, Monica certainly isn't the heroine of Flytrap. She did seduce a married man, damage the presidency for the sake of casual sex, lie frequently and insouciantly, and blab her "secret" affair to anyone who'd listen. But she was also sexually exploited by her older, sleazy boss; had her reputation smeared by Clinton's lackeys; and was betrayed by her "friend" Linda Tripp. She hardly deserves such universal contempt. 

         Others besides Currie have benefited from the public's excessive generosity. George Stephanopoulos has become a white knight of Flytrap, the former Clinton aide who had the courage to turn on his boss. And bravo to George for chastising Clinton! But it smacks of hypocrisy for Stephanopoulos to "discover" in 1998 that Clinton is a lying, womanizing dog. He has, after all known this since 1992. Back then Stephanopoulos himself helped quell bimbo eruptions and parroted Clinton's lying denials. He has never shouldered blame for those deceptions. (Mickey Kaus first noted Stephanopoulos' unbearable sanctimony in this "Chatterbox" item in January.) And while loyalty isn't a universal good, it was opportunistic for Stephanopoulos to betray Clinton just at the moment Clinton's stock was about to plunge. 

          (Sometimes, of course, the public's rating is dead on target. Linda Tripp's allies--a group that includes her lawyers, Kenneth Starr, the Goldberg family, and absolutely no one else as far as I can tell--have tried repeatedly to improve her sorry public image. Jonah Goldberg tried right here in Slate. No sale.) 

          Below is                    Slate                's entire scorecard, which ranks 31 of Flytrap's key players: The scale runs from -10 to +10. Anything less than zero means the player is a net miscreant. Anything above zero rates a sympathy card. (This is not, of course, an exact science. How, for example, do we judge Ann Lewis compared to other last ditch Clinton defenders? Lewis is said to be more outraged by Clinton's misbehavior than The Guys in the White House. Yet Lewis didn't quit in disgust. Is her outrage a plus or a minus if she doesn't act on it? You decide.)
